instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5_G3S: What is PP5_G3S? This is a typo of  When you see PP3V3_S0_DDC_LCD, assume they meant to type .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no turn on (<SIGNAL>PP5_G3S</SIGNAL> low)
threads.message:
Hello, this is a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that came attached 5v 0A

In the reads, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5_G3S</SIGNAL> were shorted. I injected 1v to those rails and found that <CAPACITOR>C7675</CAPACITOR> <TRANSISTOR>Q7660</TRANSISTOR> was damaged.
By removing these components <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> has a reading in diode mode of 0.456v but <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> is still under 0.042v (diode mode) and I inject 1v and I don't get significant consumption.
I removed <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> just in case but I have the same problem

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no turn on (<SIGNAL>PP5_G3S</SIGNAL> low)
threads.message:
I hope you didn't connect the charger without <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>.

Overvoltage went from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> through <TRANSISTOR>Q7660</TRANSISTOR>.
So any chip connected there is suspect now.
Some chips have series resistor (like <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR>).
Remove such resistor, where available, and check again diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>5V_G3S</SIGNAL>.
